a.title: Return to the homepage on the district site.

span.p: Due to the concerns over the spreading COVID-19 virus, the HCUSD#3 will begin the school closure starting March 16th, 2020 and continue through April 30, 2020 as of this time. The district has developed a remote learning plan. Click here to view the plan.

ul.li: There is a Continuous Learning Plan in place at HCUSD#3. There is online and a paper option for all classes. If you need a paper option delivered, please call your child's school.

Beginning Monday, March 23rd, all offices will be closed to the public. Staff will continue to be available at each office to take phone calls and help coordinate with those employees working from home.
Meal delivery has begun. Breakfast and lunch will be delivered to all students in need. Please call your child’s school to sign up for this service if you wish to be added to the list.
All extra-curricular activities, meetings, practices and sporting events are cancelled during the closure.

Any K-12th grade student who has internet access but needs a computer device may borrow a Chromebook during the closure. Call your child's school to make arrangments for a 6-12th grader to borrow a Chromebook.
If you or your child need any assistance during this closure, please contact our schools. The physical and emotional health and safety of students still remains our district’s primary focus.

span.p: Stay tuned to this site for updated information. THANK YOU for your patience in this unprecedented situation.

div.span: If you are having trouble viewing the document, you may download the document.

span.p: To learn about the Continous Learning plans for your student, please click on the name of your school listed above in the black bar.

Beckemeyer: 217-532-6994
Coffeen: 217-534-2314
Jr. High 217-532-3742
High School 217-532-2841
Unit Office: 217-532-2942

span.a: Center for Disease Control and Prevention

p.span: Elementary
Switcheroo Zoo-Watch, listen and play games to learn all about amazing animals!
Nat Geo for Kids-Learn all about geography and fascinating animals!
Into the Book-Go "into the book" to play games that practice reading strategies!
Suessville-Read, play games, and hangou out with Dr. Seuss and his friends!
ABCya-Practice math and reading skills all while playing fun games!
Fun Brain-Play games while practicing math and reading skills!
PBS Kids-Hang out with your favorite characters all while learning!
Star Fall-Practice your phonics skills with these read-along stories!
Storyline Online-Have some of your favorite stories read to you by movie stars!
Highlights Kids-Read, play games, and conduct coll science experiments!

span.a: 1st Grade-8th Grade Reading and Math Lessons

p.span: World Book Online- articles, activities, and games for all ages (username- wbsupport, password- distancelearn)
Learning Without Tears- handwriting materials for PreK-5th grade
Keyboarding Without Tears- keyboarding materials for kindergarten-5th grade
Little Sports YouTube Channel-Web and App based,Ages: 4+, Physical Education, Exercise and movement videos, 9- 21 minutes in length
Creation Station- created by Ms. Kumlin (HHS Art Teacher), this site focuses on art and creativity
Distance Learning for Special Education- online resources, tips for families, and more

h3.span: GoNoodle Family, Web-based, Ages: 5+, Variety, with a focus on movement and music Overview on Common Sense Media
CSFirst, Web-based and App-based, 4-10, Subjects: Variety, with focus on Coding

MakerStations, 3 Free Weeks of Maker Stations Each challenge includes instructions using materials around the house, QR code video resources, and a student recording sheet, Parent support and supervision may be necessary for some activities,

span.span: Teach Outside the Box Facebook Page

h3.span: Khan Academy Kids, App-based - iOS, Android, Kindle Fire, Ages 3+, Focus on Math, Get set up as a parent. Overview from Common Sense Media
Prodigy - Math Game, Web and App based, Ages 7+, Grades 1-8, Recommend to select ‘Play Offline’, as online play allows chat, Get set up as a parent, Overview on Common Sense Media
DreamBox, Web-based, Grades: K-8, Math, Parents can register free for 90 days, Getting started, Overview on Common Sense Media
Epic! - Kids’ Books and Videos, Web and App based, Ages 2-12, Subjects: Variety, with a focus on Reading, Get set up as a parent for a free 30-day trial, Overview on Common Sense Media
Dogo News, Web-based, Ages 9+, Subjects: Variety, with focus on Current Events, Get your child signed up, Overview on Common Sense Media
Scholastic Learn at Home, Web-based, Grades: PreK-6+, Subjects: Variety, with a focus on reading, Get set up as a parent, Parent support and guidance may be necessary for some activities

span.span: Accounts are not necessary when you access via the Curriculum Page

span.a: Supporting Individuals with Autism through Uncertain Times

p.span: VideoConferencing Communications Tools and Learning Management Systems

li.span: Distance Learning from Newsela - Newsela is providing free full access to all districts and schools for the remainder of the year.
Seesaw - Digital portfolio sharing
Remind - Communication and file sharing tool. Works via text for students who may have texting but do not have laptops. Educators can have conversations and send out assignments attached to the text.
Nearpod - Student engagement platform
Big Blue Button - Online conferencing tool for educators
Canvas​ - Learning Management System

p.span: Video Recordings and Lecture Assistance

li.span: ​Flipgrid - Create threaded video conversations on an easy to use phone app
Screencastify - Educators can record screens/lectures to share.
Edpuzzle - Video creation tool
Camtasia - Screen recorder & video editor
Flippity.net - “You turn Google spreadsheets into activities like flashcards or card sorts.”

Pear Deck - This plug-in works with Google Slides and PowerPoint. It is a way to engage students both in student self-paced mode or to project your slides to their devices while you lecture remotely (with some valuable “check in” tools). Pear Deck is offering a 90-day premium trial if your school is impacted by closures.
Kahoot​ - An online review/quizzing system. Kahoot is offering premium to schools impacted by shutdowns ​

p.span: General Curriculum Assistance

span.a: UNESCO: Distance learning solutions to mitigate COVID-19 school closures

li.span: The Learning Network via the New York Times.
List of typing websites for students to practice typing skills.
Read Theory Online reading activities for all levels with interactive items.
STEM- Teach Engineering​ - Search engineering skills aligned to curriculum by grade. ​
World Book Online- username- wbsupport, password- distancelearn

span.span: Lightbox and AV2 World Languages, free through June 30, 2020, social studies, language, arts, math and more in 10 different languages

p.span: Social Science

li.span: ​EDSITEment! from the National Endowment for the Humanities​ has a collection of classroom-ready lessons and materials for K-12 social studies education.
C3 Teachers/Student Inquiries - C3 Teachers is pleased to publish these inquiries collected at different grade levels in a vary to content topics from around the country.
Annenberg Learner/Social Studies & History - A collection of lesson plans related to teaching a variety of social studies topics.

New Visions Social Studies has developed a strong scope and sequence for Global History and Geography I, Global History and Geography II, and US History and Government. Through the investigation and analysis of primary and secondary sources, students have the opportunity to think critically, and to read, write, and speak like historians, while simultaneously honing literacy and critical thinking skills.
Newseum - First Amendment and Media Literacy
Search for lesson plans and discussion topics among other resources

World 101 - Understand the issues, forces, and actors that shape our world. From essays and discussion questions to glossaries and up-to-date reading lists, World101 provides comprehensive teaching resources for each of their modules.
The World's Largest Lesson​ in partnership with UNICEF introduces the sustainable development goals to children and young people everywhere. ​

p.span: Civics and Government

li.span: iCivics provides free resources that engage students in meaningful civic learning.
Center on Representative Government - These interactive learning modules​ are a nice introduction to how Congress works, what members of Congress do, and the importance of citizen participation.

p.span: Personal Finance and Economics

li.span: ​EconEdLink - Brought to you by the Council for Economic Education this collection of curated resources that align with different economic and personal finance ideals. Collections will help guide you and your students through different discussion areas.

Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis - Their free economics and personal finance lessons, activities, and readings provide flexibility and real-world connections, making it easier to prepare students with 21st century skills for college and career readiness.

Kiddynomics​: An Economics Curriculum for Young Learners is a set of lessons designed to introduce young children to the economic way of thinking. Informed decision-making is a critical thinking skill that students can use throughout their school, personal, and work lives.

EVERFI K-12 Financial Education - Financial education is more than being able to add dollars and cents. It’s about building better spending habits, instilling confidence, and equipping the next generation with the skills to pursue big financial goals with minimal risk. EVERFI partners with sponsors nationwide to offer interactive, online financial literacy resources to K-12 schools free of charge.

p.span: Geography

li.span: ​Mapping the World - These modules are a collection of web-based resources for educators at the American Geographical Society Library.
GeoHistory - A collection of GeoHistory lessons from the Arizona Geographic Alliance.
National Geographic​ - Bring National Geographic to your classroom through lesson plans, maps, and reference resources.

p.span: History

li.span: ​Stanford History Education Group

Reading Like A Historian engages students in historical inquiry. Each lesson revolves around a central historical question and features a set of primary documents designed for groups of students with a range of reading skills.

Beyond the Bubble unlocks the vast digital archive of the Library of Congress to create History Assessments of Thinking (HATs). Explore over 80 easy-to-use assessments that measure students' historical thinking rather than recall of facts.

Civic Online Reasoning - Students are confused about how to evaluate online information. The COR curriculum provides free lessons and assessments that help you teach students to evaluate online information that affects them, their communities, and the world.
UMBC Center for History Education - History Labs are a guided approach to historical inquiry for students in the K-12 classroom.

America in Class from the National Humanities Center - The lessons present challenging primary resources in a classroom-ready format, with background information and strategies that enable teachers and students to subject texts and images to analysis through close reading.
Docs Teach from the National Archives - This online tool for teaching with documents has a collection of activities and lesson plans crafted by educators using documents from the National Archives.
Historical Thinking Matters - Each student investigations include a short movie, historical sources, guiding questions, and an essay prompt that can be emailed to the teacher.

Big History Project - A free, online social studies course that emphasizes skill development as students draw mind-blowing connections between past, present and future. BHP delivers a big picture look at the world, and helps students develop a framework to organize what they’re learning both in and out of school.
Digital History Reader (U.S. History) and European History- This online learning experience is designed to enable students to develop the analytical skills employed by historians.

Civil War Inquiries - Inquiries feature telegram sources and all the materials needed for 2-4 days of instruction on a range of Civil War topics. The inquiries are designed using a new approach to designing instruction for social studies called the Inquiry Design Model (IDM)​. Each inquiry includes a Blueprint overview of the lesson along with descriptions of the various tasks that make up the inquiry. ​

p.span: Math

li.span: WolframMathWorld - Part of the family of free online services from Wolfram Research. These include Wolfram|Alpha, the world's first computational knowledge engine; Wolfram Demonstrations Project, an open-code resource that uses dynamic computation to illuminate concepts in mathematics; MathWorld, the number one mathematics website; as well as The Wolfram Functions Site, WolframTones, and more.

teacher.desmos.com: free to use, requires you to create an account if you do not have one. Some training may be required prior to using. Teachers can create a class code for an activity and monitor students live as they work, control the pacing and conduct discourse (will need to be in a virtual meeting for the class discourse). Middle-High School level.
Illustrative Mathematics: free resources (tasks aligned to content standards) that can be printed and used with students K-12.
Khan Academy-Math: A variety of free lessons across grades K-12, including lessons from Illustrative Mathematics and Eureka Math/EngageNY.
YouCubed: A variety of free tasks and more that can be used with students
GeoGebra​: Free classroom resources; teachers and students will need to have an understanding of how to manipulate the sliders. Middle – High School level. ​

p.span: Physical Education

li.span: ​American Heart Association
Darbee​ ​

p.span: Visual and Performing Arts

li.span: ​All Arts – Smithsonian Institute free resources for kids, (a variety of different activities on a variety of different topics, including many cross- and interdisciplinary offerings that reinforce the arts across the curriculum)
Musical Arts – (free resource, contains a series of interactive music theory lessons for students at all levels, presented in sequence with activities to practice ear training and writing skills)
Visual Art – The Louvre Abu Dhabi collection​, (an interactive journey through many pieces in the Louvre’s Abu Dhabi collection, which “aims to tell the story of human creativity”)

Theatre Arts – American Theatre Wing, (“working in the theatre” is a video series that ATW has produced that guides students through the many components of what it means to work in the theatre, including but not limited to acting, directing, producing, set design, costuming, etc.)

Dance Arts – The Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts​, (These resources need to be framed for students ahead of time, but this site contains a variety of different units that would give students the opportunity to learn about different dance topics that connect to their current learning) ​
Creation Station- This site was created by Ms. Kumlin to encourage students to explore their creativity.

span.a: Supporting Individuals with Autism through Uncertain Times

div.p: Junior Library Guild (elementary, middle school, and high school)- no sign-in needed
Destiny (grades K-5)- after clicking the link, choose Beckemeyer and search "ebooks" to view the free ebooks for our students
Scholastic At Home- select the grade band for appropriate resources (ebooks, articles, and activities)
Abdo Digital (grades K-6)- free digital bookshelf
Authors and Publishers- around the world, authors and publishers are doing live readings and activities
Continuous Learning Resources- guidance from ISBE and compiled resources for teachers during the closure
Creative Station- this site was created by Ms. Kumlin to encourage students to explore creatively.

p.span: - Create threaded video conversations on an easy to use phone app

ul.li: Blackboard Web Community Manager Privacy Policy (Updated) |
